nodes.text: Teacher test-score value-added (VA) measures predict teachers' long-term impacts on students' adult outcomes and thus can be used to evaluate teacher quality
Linked administrative school records (grades 3–8, 1989–2009) for a large urban district to federal tax records (1996–2011) to track ~1.1 million students into adulthood
Estimated teacher test-score VA using leave-year-out predictions controlling for lagged scores and rich student and class covariates; normalized VA by subject and school level
Used two empirical designs: (A) cross-classroom comparisons conditional on observables; (B) quasi-experimental cohort comparisons exploiting teacher turnover within school-grade cells

Identification assumptions: (i) selection on observables for cross-class comparisons; (ii) high-frequency teacher turnover uncorrelated with cohort quality for quasi-experiment; (iii) forecast unbiasedness of leave-out VA estimates

Constructed adult outcomes from tax data: W-2 earnings (capped), total income, 1098-T college attendance, earnings-based college quality, zip-code neighborhood measures, 401(k) contributions, and teenage birth proxy
Analysis dataset: 6.8 million student-subject-year observations covering 1.1 million students with ~89% match to tax data; sample restricted to grades 4–8 and cohorts observable in adulthood
Addressed measurement error and correlated estimation noise by using leave-year-out VA estimates and teacher fixed effects when constructing residual outcomes
Trimmed top 1% of VA outliers due to suspected test manipulation and clustered standard errors at school-cohort level to account for correlated errors
Cross-classroom design result: one standard deviation higher teacher VA in a single grade raises college attendance at age 20 by ~0.82 percentage points and college quality by ~$299

Cross-classroom earnings result: one standard deviation higher teacher VA in a single grade raises annual earnings at age 28 by about 1.3–1.65 percent (baseline 1.34%), equivalent to ~$7,000 present value at age 12 or ~$39,000 undiscounted lifetime earnings per student

Quasi-experimental (teacher turnover) result: a one standard deviation improvement in mean teacher VA across cohorts raises college attendance by ~0.86 percentage points and college quality by ~$198, validating causal interpretation for college outcomes

Other adult outcomes: higher teacher VA reduces teenage birth probability (−0.61 pp), raises neighborhood SES (percent college grads +0.25 pp), and increases 401(k) participation (+0.55 pp); teacher VA effects on test scores fade quickly but reemerge in adulthood

Heterogeneity: impacts slightly larger for females; English teacher VA has larger long-term impacts per unit test-score gain than math; impacts present across grades 4–8 and roughly constant in percentage terms by parent income

Policy simulation: replacing teachers in bottom 5% of true VA with average teacher would raise present value of students' lifetime income by ~$14,500 per student (~$407,000 per classroom); selection based on 3 years of VA data yields ~$185,000–$266,000 per classroom due to estimation error and drift; retention bonuses yield smaller net gains because many retained teachers would have stayed

Limitations and cautions: VA can be contaminated by cheating or teaching-to-test when used for high-stakes evaluation; VA captures only impacts correlated with test-score gains and may understate other teacher effects; estimates ignore general equilibrium and some cost considerations
